docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: If, as David Brooks says, we're in the middle of a moral revolution in America (the divorce rates are declining, teenage pregnancy is down, parenting is better and so on), then why nearly every day do I hear some fundamentalist Christian describe how this country is so morally corrupt as to be unlivable?

docs.lead_paragraph: Judge John G. Roberts Jr., President Bush's nominee for the Supreme Court, has written quite a bit in opposition to a constitutional right to privacy that has served as the basis for Supreme Court decisions protecting abortion and gay rights. But his writings, though distinctive and consistent, were always on behalf of superiors and clients and might not reflect his own views, then or now. The positions Judge Roberts sketched out do echo those of Robert H. Bork, whose nomination for the court was defeated in 1987.

headline.main: Privacy Views: Roberts Argued Hard for Others

docs.abstract: Supreme Court nominee John G Roberts Jr has written in opposition to constitutional right to privacy that has served as basis for Supreme Court decisions protecting abortion and gay rights; his writings, though distinctive and consistent, were always on behalf of superiors and clients and might not reflect his own views, then or now; but those positions do echo those of Robert H Bork, whose nomination for court was defeated in 1987 largely because his writings claimed there is no constitutional right to privacy; liberal and conservative law professors agree that Roberts could face serious trouble if he were to embrace similar views at his confirmation hearings in Senate; in two years on federal appeals court, Roberts addressed significant privacy issues only in his Fourth Amendment decisions, but there is little overlap between Fourth Amendment doctrine and sort of constitutional privacy rights involved in cases concerning broader social issues (M)
docs.snippet: Judge John G. Roberts Jr.'s writings in opposition to a constitutional right to privacy might not reflect his own views.
